The "Fisheries Restoration and Irrigation Mitigation Act of 2000" establishes the Fisheries Restoration and Irrigation Mitigation Program, defining terms like Pacific Ocean drainage area and Secretary. The Fisheries Restoration and Irrigation Mitigation Program aims to reduce fish mortality caused by water withdrawals for irrigation without hindering water use. Projects will be developed to mitigate impacts on fisheries from water diversions in the Pacific Ocean drainage area. The Fisheries Restoration and Irrigation Mitigation Program focuses on reducing fish mortality from irrigation water withdrawals in the Pacific Ocean drainage area. Eligible projects include fish screens, fish passage devices, and other related features. The Secretary prioritizes projects costing less than $5,000,000. SEC. 4. PARTICIPATION IN THE PROGRAM. Non-Federal participation is voluntary, and the Secretary will not hold non-Federal entities financially responsible unless they choose to participate. Federal expenditures for projects on U.S. land are nonreimbursable. SEC. 5. EVALUATION AND PRIORITIZATION OF PROJECTS. Evaluation and prioritization of projects for development under the Program is based on benefits to native fish species, size and type of water diversion, availability of funding sources, cost effectiveness, and additional opportunities for biological or water delivery system benefits. Eligibility requirements are also outlined. Eligibility requirements for projects under the Program include meeting Secretary and State requirements, agreement by all relevant entities, consultation with various agencies, and utilization of available data. Non-Federal participants in projects under the Program must provide 35% of the cost for development and implementation on non-government-owned land or facilities. They are also responsible for providing necessary land, easements, rights-of-way, and other resources for the project, which will be credited towards their share of the project costs. Non-Federal participants in projects under the Program must provide 35% of the cost for development and implementation on non-government-owned land or facilities. They are responsible for all costs associated with operating, maintaining, repairing, rehabilitating, and replacing the project. The Federal Government is responsible for costs for projects on Federal land or at a Federal facility. SEC. 8. LIMITATION ON ELIGIBILITY FOR FUNDING. Projects funded under this Act cannot receive funds from any other Federal source for the same purpose.

SEC. 9. REPORT. After three fiscal years of funding, the Secretary must report to Congress on completed projects, those to be completed in future years, and recommended Program changes based on project outcomes.

SEC. 10. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Authorization of Appropriations: $25,000,000 authorized annually for fiscal years 2001-2005. Limitations include not more than 25% of funds for projects in a single state, with a waiver option, and a cap of 6% for federal administrative expenses. The curr_chunk can be summarized as:
